questions.question: How is the coronavirus transmitted?
questions.answer: Evidence suggests that COVID spreads mainly from person to person, primarily through respiratory droplets that are released when a person sneezes, coughs, or talks. These droplets are propelled through the air and can land in the noses and mouths of people, especially those in close proximity (six feet or less), according to the [Centers for Disease Control](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html) (CDC) and [World Health Organization](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/question-and-answers-hub/q-a-detail/q-a-how-is-covid-19-transmitted?gclid=Cj0KCQjwqrb7BRDlARIsACwGad6u8LD7qnGFt5oFPYI4ngBzLUHYz2-9DZ_b4fruyio4ekVFoQR7l7YaAsm3EALw_wcB) (WHO). [Research](https://www.pnas.org/content/117/26/14857) supported by the CDC also suggests that COVID may spread through aerosol, or airborne, transmission. This is similar to transmission by droplets except that the amounts of fluid are much smaller and can linger in the air for a much longer time and infect people further than six feet away.

questions.question: How long does the virus live on surfaces?
questions.answer: The virus can live from several hours to several days on surfaces, depending on the type of material (cardboard, plastic, etc.). Even so, the CDC says that COVID is not transmitted easily through surfaces and spreads mainly from person-to-person. If you are concerned about surface contamination, you can find details on appropriate cleaning and sanitizing protocols from the CDC [here](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/pdf/Reopening_America_Guidance.pdf#:~:text=Coronaviruses%20on%20surfaces%20and%20objects,and%20dirt%20from%20surfaces.).

questions.question: Which individuals are most vulnerable to COVID?
questions.answer: Anyone who has been exposed to COVID is at risk of contracting the disease, and people of all ages have experienced hospitalization and death. Some people, however, are at greater risk. Elderly individuals, particularly those 85 or older, and people with certain underlying medical conditions are at higher risk of serious illness, according to the CDC. (Click [here](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/people-at-increased-risk.html) for information from the CDC about people at increased risk.)

questions.question: Which demographic groups are most likely to become infected with COVID, to become seriously ill, or to die from the virus?
questions.answer: Data from the CDC show that race and ethnicity, similar to age, are risk factors for COVID. In fact, the rates of COVID cases, hospitalizations and deaths among Blacks, Hispanic and Latino persons, and American Indians and Native Alaskans are much higher than for white people, according to the agency’s calculation of [COVID-19 Hospitalization and Death by Race/Ethnicity](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/investigations-discovery/hospitalization-death-by-race-ethnicity.html) (updated August 18, 2020). Some data show an even higher mortality rate among certain ethnic and racial groups than the CDC data. The [APM Research Lab](https://www.apmresearchlab.org/covid/deaths-by-race) finds that death rates are more than three times higher for Blacks, Latinos, and Indigenous people than for white people (update September 15).

questions.question: What are the long-term effects of COVID?
questions.answer: While some people recover quickly from COVID, others suffer debilitating, long-term symptoms, according to the [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/coronavirus/in-depth/coronavirus-long-term-effects/art-20490351). In Italy, which was one of the first countries to be hit hard by the disease, many survivors are still experiencing health problems after having COVID. In one [study](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2768351), more than 87 percent of individuals experienced one or more symptoms (most commonly fatigue and difficulty breathing) after recovery from COVID. Meanwhile, a German [study](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamacardiology/fullarticle/2768916) found that 78 of 100 recovered COVID patients continued to experience heart abnormalities months after infection.

questions.question: When is an infected person considered recovered?
questions.answer: According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/disposition-in-home-patients.html), a person with COVID who has been isolating at home may discontinue isolation when (1) at least 10 days have passed since symptom onset; (2) at least 24 hours have passed fever-free without the use of fever-reducing medications; and (3) other symptoms have improved. Those “who never develop symptoms may discontinue isolation and other precautions 10 days after the date of their first positive” PCR test for COVID-19.

questions.question: How common are asymptomatic cases?
questions.answer: Many individuals infected with COVID are asymptomatic (that is, they do not manifest symptoms of the virus), which makes COVID much harder to control. When people do not know that they are ill, they do not take precautions. In much the same way, people who are “pre-symptomatic” – that is, they will eventually develop symptoms ‒ may unknowingly spread the disease to others before they realize that they are ill. The [CDC estimates](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/planning-scenarios.html) that 40 percent of COVID cases are asymptomatic (Scenario 5, updated as of July 10, 2020, gives the CDC’s “Current Best Estimate” and cites the relevant literature).

questions.question: What is counted as a COVID death?
questions.answer:
The [WHO](https://www.who.int/classifications/icd/Guidelines_Cause_of_Death_COVID-19.pdf?ua=1) states that a COVID death can be “a death resulting from a clinically compatible illness, in a probable or confirmed COVID-19 case, unless there is a clear alternative cause of death that cannot be related to COVID disease (e.g. trauma). There should be no period of complete recovery from COVID-19 between illness and death.” (You can find the CDC’s guidance on reporting and coding deaths due to COVID [here](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/covid19/coding-and-reporting.htm).)

Tracking the number of COVID deaths is difficult, and some suggest that the number is underreported. One issue is that individuals infected with the virus may be sick for many days, or even weeks, before death, so the increase in deaths resulting from a wave of infections may lag significantly in time. In some cases people may die indirectly from COVID, because hospitals were overcrowded with COVID patients and care was late or unavailable. To track the number of COVID deaths, researchers rely on something called “excess mortality” — the number of deaths from all causes during a crisis that are above the historical average during non-crisis times. For information on excess mortality, see the CDC’s report, [Excess Deaths Associated with COVID-19](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/vsrr/covid19/excess_deaths.htm).

questions.question: Why is testing important?
questions.answer: Diagnostic testing allows health officials to identify and isolate infected individuals and begin contact tracing to quarantine people who were exposed. It also allows public health officials to collect the data and information necessary to know when it is safe to resume ordinary activities or when non-pharmaceutical interventions like masks are critical. Leaders of the [American Heart Association](https://healthmetrics.heart.org/covid-19-science-why-testing-is-so-important/), the [American Medical Association](https://www.ama-assn.org/delivering-care/public-health/why-cdc-was-right-revise-coronavirus-testing-guidelines) and the [National Institute on Aging](https://www.nia.nih.gov/news/why-covid-19-testing-key-getting-back-normal), among other organizations, have all urged for an expansion of testing.

questions.question: Why is a low positive test rate a good sign?
questions.answer: Many people infected with COVID are pre-symptomatic or asymptomatic, making it difficult to know how widespread the disease is in a community. If there is ample testing being done, including of individuals who have no reason to believe that they have the virus, then many negative test results will be received, leading to a low test positivity rate. This is an indication that adequate testing is being done in an area and that there are not a lot of undetected cases in the community. (See our [blog](https://blog.covidactnow.org/test-positivity-explained/) for more information on test positivity rates).

questions.question: When tests are conducted, where do the results get counted?
questions.answer: State reporting practices differ. In most states, the test results are reported where individuals are tested, not where they live. Florida, however, distinguishes between residents and non-residents in the statistics it publishes.

questions.question: Does CAN's positive test rate metric show PCR or PCR and Serology test results?
questions.answer: We get our state testing data from [The Covid Tracking Project,](https://covidtracking.com/) which aggregates the data from the states’ dashboards. No state should mix the results of diagnostic tests (including PCR tests and antigen tests) with the results of antibody tests. Serology tests looking for COVID antibodies can identify individuals who have had the virus at some point in the past, but they should not be used to diagnose an active COVID infection, according to the Food and Drug Administration’s [Coronavirus Testing Basics](https://www.fda.gov/consumers/consumer-updates/coronavirus-testing-basics). Some states, at various times, have included both diagnostic and antibody tests in their reports. We make every possible effort to obtain data that is not corrupted, but ultimately we must work with the data that is available.

questions.question: What is pool testing?
questions.answer: Pooled testing is a process in which samples — such as PCR nasal swabs — are collected and tested in a batch, or pool, rather than individually. If the pool comes back positive, one or more of the people in the pool may be infected, and each sample must be tested again individually. The hope is that by pooling samples, there will be fewer overall tests, saving testing supplies and allowing more tests to be run at a time, according to the [FDA](https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-issues-first-emergency-authorization-sample-pooling-diagnostic), which approved pooled testing for Quest Diagnostics in July.

questions.question: What is R-nought (R0) and how is it different from R(t)?
questions.answer: R-nought (R0) represents the natural ability of a virus to spread in an unprotected population where no special precautions are being taken. R(t), in contrast, takes into account public health measures or the development of a vaccine. This makes R(t) —the actual or “effective” spread of the virus under current conditions —  a more accurate reflection of the number of people that a single infected person is expected to infect in a specific area at a specific time. It is also more relevant than R0 in directing public policy and informing private behavior. The value of R(t) can change over time, depending on such factors as how many people are staying home or wearing masks. At Covid Act Now, we look at R(t), because it represents more closely what is happening right now and is calculated based on actual death and hospitalization data. You can read about where our data comes from in this [blog post](https://blog.covidactnow.org/where-does-our-data-come-from/) and in our [Assumptions and References document](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1cd_cEpNiIl1TzUJBvw9sHLbrbUZ2qCxgN32IqVLa3Do/edit). If you would like to visit a website that calculates R(t) every day for each state, and then displays both the historical and current information, visit [Rt Live](https://rt.live/).

questions.question: What is contact tracing?
questions.answer: Contact tracing is an effective strategy for slowing the spread of COVID. It involves finding out who has been in close contact with an individual infected with COVID, letting those people know that they may have been exposed, and guiding them on what they should do next. The work of contact tracers can be extremely labor-intensive and difficult, given that many contacts are difficult to identify and locate. After informing people that they are at risk for the infection, contact tracers provide advice on quarantine procedures and testing. For further information on contact tracing efforts in the U.S., please visit our partner, [TestandTrace.com](https://testandtrace.com/).
